origins.title: Origins
origins.content: Nuada Airgetlam was the first king of the Tuatha De Danann, the divine race that descended upon Ireland in a great fleet shrouded in magical mist. His lineage traces to Echtach, son of Etarlam, connecting him to the primordial divine ancestry of the Tuatha De. As their sovereign, Nuada led his people from their mystical northern islands (often identified with the otherworldly realms) to claim Ireland from the Fir Bolg. He possessed one of the Four Treasures of the Tuatha De Danann: the Cla√≠omh Solais (Sword of Light), brought from the city of Findias, which no enemy could escape once it was drawn.

mythology.title: Mythology
mythology.content: Nuada's defining myth is the First Battle of Moytura against the Fir Bolg. Though the Tuatha De Danann won, Nuada lost his right arm to the Fir Bolg champion Sreng. Under the law that a king must be physically unblemished (a doctrine called 'r√≠ge fri sofholta'), Nuada was forced to abdicate. The half-Fomorian Bres became king but proved tyrannical. The physician-god Dian Cecht crafted Nuada a functional arm of silver, hence his epithet 'Airgetl√°m' (Silver Hand/Arm). Later, Dian Cecht's son Miach grew Nuada a new arm of flesh, fully restoring him. Nuada reclaimed his throne and led his people in the Second Battle of Moytura against the Fomorians. Though Lugh ultimately defeated the Fomorian champion Balor, Nuada fell in that great battle, slain by Balor's deadly eye before Lugh could intervene.

attributes.title: Attributes
attributes.content: Nuada embodies the ideal of sacred kingship - the king who is one with the land and whose wholeness ensures the prosperity of his people. His silver hand represents both the price of sovereignty and the possibility of divine restoration. The Sword of Light he carries is invincible, symbolizing the king's role as final arbiter of justice. Though a warrior, Nuada's greatest quality is his willingness to step aside for the good of his people - abdicating when blemished, returning only when whole. He corresponds to the Romano-British god Nodens, worshipped at Lydney in Gloucestershire, associated with healing, the sea, and hunting.

culturalRole.title: Cultural Role
culturalRole.content: Nuada represents the Celtic concept of the king as sacred intermediary between gods and people. His story illustrates the harsh requirements of divine kingship - the ruler must be perfect in body to channel the land's fertility. The silver hand became an enduring symbol of Ireland's mythic heritage and the transformative power of the gods. Medieval Irish genealogies traced royal lineages back to Nuada, legitimizing dynastic claims through divine descent. His worship likely continued into the Romano-British period as Nodens, whose temple at Lydney featured healing rituals and votive offerings. Nuada's ultimate sacrifice in battle against the forces of chaos (the Fomorians) established the pattern of the king who dies defending his people.

description: Nuada Airgetlam ('Silver Hand') is the first and greatest king of the Tuatha De Danann, the divine race of Irish mythology. He led his people to Ireland and defeated the Fir Bolg at the First Battle of Moytura, but lost his right arm to the champion Sreng. Under Celtic law requiring kings to be physically unblemished, Nuada had to abdicate until the physician-god Dian Cecht crafted him a fully functional arm of silver. Restored to wholeness, Nuada reclaimed his throne and wielded the Cla√≠omh Solais (Sword of Light), one of the Four Treasures of the Tuatha De Danann. He fell in the Second Battle of Moytura, slain by the Fomorian king Balor before Lugh could defeat that terrible foe. Nuada embodies the Celtic ideal of sacred kingship: the ruler whose physical perfection mirrors the health of the land, and who sacrifices himself defending his people.
